As for CNTs, despite their high electrical conductivity and large SSA, the intrinsic impurities caused by catalyst reactions and high cost hamper their efficient use.
In this sense, graphene is an excellent alternative to conventional carbon electrode materials. Graphene possesses superior physicochemical stability, electrical conductivity, and larger theoretical specific surface area than most conventional carbon materials. Additionally, it also has excellent flexibility and tensile strength, beneficial for possible applications in flexible electrodes.[22–25] These properties
make graphene-based nanomaterials the ideal electrode material for electrochemical devices, such as batteries or supercapacitors, which are used in micro-electromechanical systems, electric vehicles, portable electronic devices, etc.
For the purpose of this article, a wider definition of “graphene” will be used that includes reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as well. Over the last decade, numerous electrode materials based on graphene have been investigated and tested for cycle stability and their specific capacity.[26–37] However, despite serious research efforts in graphene-based electrochemical energy storage devices, the market demand for higher performance is steadily increasing. In the case of lithium-ion batteries, lithium ions have to make a big detour to reach the electrolyte since they cannot pass through the 2D graphene sheets. This results in a long diffusion distance and consequently a slow charge–discharge rate for lithium-ion batteries.[38,39] Supercapacitors can store electrical charge proportional to the surface area of their conductive material, which makes graphene with a theoretical specific surface of 2600 m2 g−1 per sheet a very promising option.[40] Unfortunately, the widespread use of supercapacitors is limited due to the high effective series resistance and low energy storage density. Additionally, the tendency of graphene sheets to aggregate greatly reduces the real accessible surface area.
The aforementioned problems can be addressed by modifying the graphene sheets to give them a porous structure, which reduces the ion diffusion pathway and increases the
Graphene-based nanocomposites are characterized by high mechanical strength, excellent electrical conductivity, and outstanding thermal and chemical stability. Additionally, the combination of versatile functionalization chemistry and simplicity of large-scale synthesis makes graphene ideal for electrode materials for energy storage devices. To improve the electrochemical performance even further, recent research has focused on the preparation of porous graphene structures, either by creating holes in the graphene sheets or by assembling them into a 3D porous framework. Porous graphene and reduced graphene oxide allow for rapid ion diffusion and display high real surface area. In this review paper, the conventional methods for the preparation of porous graphene are summarized and recent progress in porous graphene-based nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage devices is discussed.

1. Introduction
sections.text:
The discovery of graphene has led to substantial research endeavors into its properties and possible synthesis methods. Due to its honeycomb carbon lattice that consists of only a single layer, graphene-based nanomaterials possess unique properties and show great potential for many kinds of applications.[1–9] Especially, the increasing demand for better storage devices with enhanced performance such as high power density, energy density, and cycle stability has driven researches to focus on using graphene-based materials for electrochemical applications.[10–16]
Various porous carbon materials such as activated carbon, mesoporous carbon, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), aerogels, and carbide-derived carbons are often used as electrodes.[17–21] Several crucial factors to achieve high performing electrodes include high specific surface area (SSA), pore size and

Porous graphene expands the amount of possible nanoarchitectures with excellent structural and electrical properties that can be used in many electrochemical devices.
Although porous graphene-based electrodes are used for both batteries and supercapacitors, the precise design of the electrode depends on the requirements of the specific energy storage device. Batteries function as an energy source with relatively low power density and can operate for a longer duration of time compared to supercapacitors. By utilizing electrodes with a porous structure, a battery with enhanced higher power density than its conventional capacity can be obtained and possibly be used in applications requiring high power density in addition to high energy density. On the other hand, the major feature of supercapacitor is its fast charge and discharge rate. Since the supercapacitive reactions take place on the surface of the electrode, it is important to use a material with high surface area that is easily accessible. An electrode made out of porous materials enables easier ion access to the surface and as a result better capacitance.
This review paper will go over the recent advances in the synthesis of porous graphene and the application of porous graphene in electrochemical energy storage devices. Finally, future development on further improving the performance of graphene-based nanocomposite materials will be discussed.

sections.heading: 2. Porous Graphene Synthesis Methods
sections.text: Porous graphene can be prepared through a multitude of different strategies as outlined in Table 1. These methods can be roughly categorized into two groups; the in-plane generation of pores into graphene sheets and the out-of-plane generation of a 3D porous structure.

sections.heading: 2.1. Generation of In-Plane Pores into the Graphene Sheets
sections.text:
Exposing graphene to certain solutions of acid/oxidizer can lead to carbon erosion. This process occurs when graphene oxide is treated with the acid/oxidizer solution while sonicating or by applying microwave irradiation.[44,45] Commonly used acids and oxidizers for etching graphene are HNO3 and KMnO4.
Fan et al. demonstrated that porous graphene can be prepared under microwave irradiation using KMnO4 as oxidizer,[45] as shown in Figure 1. The resulting porous graphene was characterized by pores with a size around 3 nm and a specific surface area of 1374 m2 g−1. Recently, chemically activated graphene has been prepared using bases such as KOH and NaOH. After the chemical activation process, the specific surface area of the prepared porous graphene was much closer to the theoretical value of 2600 m2 g−1.[42,48]

sections.heading: 3. Recent Advances in Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Batteries
sections.text: Batteries with high energy density and power density are an integral part of many portable devices and electric vehicles. Batteries may play a crucial role in the storage of renewable energy in an era with a growing demand for renewable energy. Yet, the progress of batteries has not kept up with the ever more demanding and stringent industry requirements. A substantial amount of effort has been made to find better electrode materials with superior electrochemical performance for batteries. Much of the research into the development of sustainable energy storage using batteries involves carbonaceous nanomaterials. Graphene can provide a carbon framework that has high specific surface area, mechanical robustness, and chemical stability. As a result, it can be an ideal host for the active material used in batteries that are inherently insulating themselves. However, graphene easily stacks together, which reduces the real surface area and consequentially the electrochemical performance. In-plane porous or out-of-plane 3D porous graphene allows the electrolyte to effectively penetrate the electrode and interact with the active material. Porous graphene simultaneously allows for fast electron transfer and ion diffusion. Additionally, careful design of a hierarchal porous structure can provide abundant active sites for ion storage. A summary of batteries that use novel porous graphene-based electrodes is shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 3.1. Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Lithium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
In the past few decades, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become one of the most popular energy storage devices. They have a higher energy density (≈400 Wh L−1) than traditional rechargeable batteries such as lead–acid, nickel–metal hydride, and nickel–cadmium batteries.[70] Ever since the practical application of LIB in 1991, steady improvements have led to better performance in terms of energy density,

power density, and life span.[71] In order to enhance the electrochemical performance, it is necessary to develop active materials that have high electric and ionic conductivity, high specific capacity, and excellent cycling stability.[71] Metal oxides and alloy-based materials are promising candidates as an alternative to the conventional graphite anode due to their high theoretical capacity.[70] However, they usually suffer from poor cycle and rate performance because of low intrinsic electric conductivity and significant volume change during cycling.[70]
The most common approach to solve these problems is to combine such active materials with carbon materials like carbon nanotube, graphene, and graphitic carbon derived from various sources.[72–74] Porous graphene has attracted much attention with its superior electric conductivity as well as ionic conductivity. For example, Wu et al. prepared Sn-based nanoparticles encapsulated in a porous 3D graphene network as LIB anode by a surfactant-assisted assembly method.[75] The resulting material (CoSnO3@pGN), as shown in Figure 8, exhibits a reversible capacity of 432 mA h g−1 at a high current density of 10 A g−1. After 1500 cycles at 2 A g−1, it shows a reversible capacity of 566 mA h g−1 with a capacity retention of 80%. The efficient electron transfer and rapid diffusion of Li ions to the CoSnO3 particles through the 3D porous conductive framework resulted in remarkable rate performance. The internal void spaces resulting from the sacrificial polystyrene
particle template can buffer the volume expansion of CoSnO3 and preserve the 3D graphene network, which result in the excellent cycle stability. Jiang et al. introduced monolayer MoS2–graphene hybrid aerogels with controllable porosity as LIB anode.[76] Due to the redox reactions occurring on the surface, monolayer MoS2 nanosheets have no lithium-ion diffusion limit. However, the monolayer MoS2 has a higher band gap (≈1.8 eV) than bulk MoS2 (≈1.2 eV) and tends to restack to become multilayer MoS2, which leads to poor electron transfer. 3D porous MoS2–graphene aerogel was synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method. The strong interaction between graphene nanosheets and MoS2 nanosheets prevents both the restacking and enhances the structural integrity. In addition, the 3D porous graphene network provides an efficient electron and ion pathway. Consequently, 3D MoS2–graphene composite electrodes show superior rate performance. It exhibits a reversible capacity of about 436 mA h g−1 at a current density of 2 A g−1 and a capacity retention of 95% after 200 cycles. Yu et al. designed ordered mesoporous graphene spheres from colloidal nanocrystals (NCs) as LIB anode, as shown in Figure 9.[77] This ordered mesoporous graphene structure ensures the structural homogeneity in the
template to synthesize homogeneous pores. After the Fe3O4 template was removed through etching with HCl and applying additional heat treatment, the ordered mesoporous graphene spheres (OMGSs) were obtained and SnO2 or GeO2 nanoparticles were incorporated in the mesoporous graphene spheres. SnO2@OMGS showed a reversible capacity of 968, 923, 778, 582, and 425 mA h g−1 at current densities of 1.2, 2, 5, 10, and 15 A g−1 and after 700 cycles at 2 A g−1, it still delivered a reversible capacity of 789 mA h g−1. The GeO2@OMGS sample exhibits a reversible capacity of 1100, 950, 730, 600, 510, and 380 mA h g−1 at 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 10 A g−1. After 500 cycles at 2 A g−1, it shows a capacity of 770 mA h g−1. This remarkable performance is due to the efficient electron and ion pathway.
In-plane porous graphene has also been utilized to develop high performance electrode material. Lee et al. introduced nanohole-structured, iron oxide-decorated, and gelatin-functionalized graphene as LIB anode.[78] Nanoholes were generated by iron oxide nanoparticles on gelatinfunctionalized graphene using microwave irradiation. At 900 W, the iron oxide nanoparticles penetrate the graphene and create pores. At the same time, the amine group from gelatin releases ammonia to form pyrrolic N at the edges of the graphene. Upon analysis, it exhibited discharge capacities of 996, 863, and 634 mA h g−1 at 0.2, 0.4, 0.8 A g−1. Even after 40 cycles, a reversible capacity of 924 mA h g−1 was observed.

sections.heading: 3.2. Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Lithium–Sulfur Batteries
sections.text:
Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries are a promising alternative to the conventional LIBs. Not only do Li–S batteries possess a high theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 and an energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1, they have the additional advantage of using sulfur, which is naturally abundant, low in cost, and nontoxic.[79,80] However, the commercialization of Li–S batteries is hindered by a combination of factors. First, sulfur and lithium sulfide are naturally insulating and therefore the addition of conductive additives is required.[81] Second, some lithium polysulfides readily dissolve in the liquid electrolyte and react with lithium at the anode, also known as the “shuttle effect.”[82,83] Finally, the sulfur undergoes large volume expansion (≈80%) during lithiation, which results in low Coulombic efficiency and fast capacity loss.[84] Although different possible solutions to these problems have been proposed, porous graphene is one of the more promising ones. The most common solution to improving the conductivity of the cathode is to use a carbonaceous host for the sulfur such as carbon nanoparticles,[85] multiwall carbon nanotubes,[86] carbonized paper,[87] etc. Graphene is an obvious choice as carbon host for both LIB and Li–S batteries due to its excellent properties, such as high electrical conductivity and good stability.[88–90] In particular, heteroatom-doped graphene shows good electrochemical performance, since the presence of charged sites increases the conductivity and adsorption capability of the graphene.[91–94] A nitrogen and phosphorus dual-doped porous graphene (p-NP-G) was prepared by Gu et al. through thermal annealing followed by hydrothermal reaction.[95] The p-NP-G consisted out of 4.38% N and 1.93% P, besides enhanced conductivity, displayed stronger adsorption of polysulfides compared to single-doped or undoped graphene. Further electrochemical analysis revealed that after loading with sulfur, the resulting Li–S battery had an initial capacity of 1158.3 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 C and a good rate capability of 633.7 mA h g−1 at 2 C. Additionally,

Dissolution and the shuttle effect are serious problems for graphene-based materials since the open structure of graphene fails to trap polysulfides. 3D graphene structures have been suggested as a solution, since its porous morphology can accommodate the volumetric expansion and immobilize the polysulfide species at the same time.[96] Xu et al. created a 3D graphene supported sulfur composite (S@3D-graphene) as cathode material through a metal ion assisted hydrothermal method.[97] The resulting material consists out of winkled and 3D connected nanosheets with pores in the range of 20–200 nm. The 3D structure provides a conductive matrix for fast ion and electron transfer and the porous inner space restrains the dissolution of polysulfides. As a result, the electrodes loaded with 73 wt% sulfur showed enhanced cycling performance with a capacity >700 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C.
Besides out-of-plane 3D porous structures, hierarchical porous graphene has been synthesized for Li–S battery applications. The wide range of pore sizes can prevent some of the aforementioned problems since different pores serve different functions. Macropores function as mass-buffering areas and help with rapid diffusion; mesopores shorten the pathway for ion migration and leaves room for expansion; micropores increase the surface area and provide abundant active sites.[98,99] Tang et al. produced hierarchical porous graphene by using porous CaO as catalyst and template during CVD.[100] Due to the combination of these different pore sizes, the resulting cathode
showed a high capacity of 357 mA h g−1 at 5.0 C, which is a 74% retention compared to the capacity at 0.1 C. Similarly, Shi et al. used a Zn–Mg–Al system as template during CVD,[101] where small pores are created in the template during calcination due to the Kirkendall diffusion and bigger pores were formed due to the evaporation of volatile metal during reduction, as shown in Figure 10. The resulting cathode was used in a Li–S battery and showed a low fading rate of around 0.04% per cycle at 1.0 C.
An additional problem of Li–S batteries is that most electrodes that have been reported in literature have a low sulfur loading (<2 mg cm−2) and low sulfur content (<70 wt%).[102–105] It is challenging to retain good electrochemical performance at a high sulfur loading, since an increase in sulfur loading decreases the Li–S battery’s performance due to sulfur’s insulation nature and an increase in dissolution of polysulfide.[106] Hu et al. created a 3D hierarchical network structure made out of graphene foam nested with reduced graphene oxide using CVD and nickel foam as a template.[107] Due to the large quantity of pores, the product could successfully be loaded with sulfur up to 14.36 mg cm−2, corresponding to a sulfur content of 89.4 wt%. When used in a Li–S battery, a high areal capacity of 10.3 mA h cm−2 at 0.2 C was obtained and 63.8% retention after 350 cycles was achieved. The macrostructure owes its good electrochemical performance to the combination of graphene with high conductivity, the functional groups of rGO, and the porous 3D network structure. He et al. tackled the problem of low sulfur by synthesizing a 3D carbon nanotube/graphene (3DCG) composite, where the 1D nanotubes can be used to tune the mesopores and improve the conductive

The 3DCG material allowed for a sulfur loading of 80.1% and a bulk conductivity much higher than the 3D graphene without nanotubes. sections.heading: 3.3. Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Sodium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered to be a promising alternative to the convention LIB due to the availability and wide distribution of sodium reserves.[6,109,110] Additionally, they have the benefit of high voltage, good charge–discharge reversibility, and safety.[111] Although the basic mechanism behind SIBs and LIBs is very similar, the bigger sized Na+ ions (radius 1.02 Å) compared to the Li+ ion (radius 0.59 Å) makes it undesirable to use conventional host materials.[112,113] For example, graphite is a carbonaceous material that is often used as anode in LIBs, but the small interlayer distance makes it unsuitable for Na+ intercalation. For efficient Na+ insertion, an interlayer distance of over 0.37 nm is crucial.[114] Although decent capacity has been achieved using hard carbon as anode material, poor cycle stability has prevented any practical applications so far. Since the diffusion of Na+ is the rate-limiting step, porous carbonaceous structures have been hypothesized to allow for improved electrochemical performance.[115,116]

Research conducted by Zhang et al. also confirmed that additional defects and edges could function as additional active sites for reversible ion storage, reduces the diffusion resistance, and shortens the diffusion length.[27,121–124] This is in accordance with theoretical studies that suggest that the absorption of ions on a single layer of pure graphene is difficult, and edges and defects play an important role.[125,126] However, the incorporation of too many defect sites will break the conjugated π bonds and make the graphene an electrical insulator.[127,128]
Metal sulfides have received broad research interest, thanks to their relatively high capacity and redox reversibility.[129,130] In particular, Sb2S3 is a promising candidate since both Sb and S can store Na+ ions, and its amorphous structure can partially avoid the volume change between cycles.[131–133] Lu et al. proposed using Sb2S5-based anode material since the more sulfur rich Sb2S5 is speculated to possess better capacity compared to Sb2S3.[134] 3D porous graphene foam was used to anchor the ≈5 nm sized Sb2S5 particles using a hydrothermal coassembly method. The 3D porous graphene foam helps to prevent aggregation of the nanoparticles, facilitates electron transfer, and buffers the volume swelling during sodiation and desodiation. The resulting electrode displayed high reversible capacity (845 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1), long cycling life (91.6% retention after 300 cycles at 0.2 A g−1), and exceptional rate capability (525 mA h g−1 at 10.0 A g−1).
Meanwhile, cathode electrodes are normally based on Na-containing layered transition metal oxides (TMOs) or polyanionic compounds.[135] Although TMOs were initially reported around 1980, they have recently attracted interest again as post-LIB system with low cost and high energy density.[136–138] In contrast, polyanionic compounds generally have a lower gravimetric capacity due to the heavy polyanion group. However, the strong covalent bonding leads to structural stability and the wide range of possible polyanion species (e.g., (SO4)2−, (SiO4)4−, (PO4)3−, and (P2O4)4−) allow for many novel open-framework crystal structures.[139,140] Among the polyanions, the Na superionic conductor type Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) in particular is of interest since the 3D framework provides diffusion pathways that facilitate rapid Na+ diffusion, while the connected interstices are ideal for reversible Na ion extraction and intercalation.[141,142] However, NVP has not reached its full potential yet, since its low electronic conductivity makes it
impossible to obtain the full theoretical capacity. Herein, Rui et al. synthesized a porous graphene network decorated with carbon coated NVP (NVP@C@rGO), as shown in Figure 11.[143] This material tries to optimize the charge transfer by utilizing small nanograins to shorten Na ion diffusion, enable rapid ion transport, buffer the strain caused by sodiation/desodiation through its macro-/mesoporous network, and facilitate fast electron transfer by incorporating 3D rGO nanosheets. The NVP@C@rGO electrode displayed high electrical conductivity and rapid Na+ ion and electron transport, which allowed the material to complete a full charge/discharge cycle in under 1 min (91 mA h g−1 at 80 C and 86 mA h g−1 at 100 C). Moreover, even after 10 000 cycles at 100 C, the macropores and the carbon structure are well preserved and the cathode displayed a capacity retention of 64%.

sections.heading: 4. Recent Advances in Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Like batteries, supercapacitors are among the most widely studied energy storage devices. Supercapacitors enable rapid and highly reversible charge and discharge of energy and have significantly higher energy density than conventional electrostatic or electrolytic capacitors. However, their practical applications are limited by still lacking energy density, and thus new electrode materials are in high demand.
Generally, the supercapacitor performance is highly dependent on the engineered pore structure and the accessible specific surface area of the electrode material, since more surface area in contact with the electrolyte means easier diffusion of ions throughout the cell. According to the charge– discharge mechanism, supercapacitors may be categorized into two major types: electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLCs), which function by charge separation at the electrode/ electrolyte interface, and redox-based electrochemical capacitors that use electrodes made out of metal oxide/hydroxide or conducting polymer and display reversible redox reactions at the electrode surface.[144–146] Carbonaceous materials usually have high conductivity and power capabilities, but energy density is generally low as the surface of the carbon is often only partially accessible.[145,147] On the other hand, metal oxides/hydroxides

sections.heading: 4.1. Porous Graphene-Based Electrodes for Electrochemical Double Layer Capacitors
sections.text:
The problem with carbonaceous materials is their low energy density due to the limited exposed surface of the carbon. In order to address this problem, attempts to increase the available surface area were made by using porous electrode materials.
For instance, Xu et al. assembled two forms of porous graphene nanostructures, including holey graphene hydrogels with 3D hierarchical perforations, and compact but porous multilayered graphene paper via mild hydrogen peroxide etching in aqueous dispersion of graphene oxide.[149] These holey graphene structures exhibit significantly higher specific surface area and ion diffusion rates over their nonholey counterparts. They can also be used directly as supercapacitor electrodes without any additional binder and feature ultrahigh volumetric and gravimetric specific capacitances of 234 F cm−3 and 283 F g−1, respectively. Moreover, remarkable cycling stability with capacitance retention of ≈90% over 20 000 charge– discharge cycles (10 A g−1) was observed.
Similarly, Bai et al. also used mild hydrogen peroxide etching followed by hydrazine-assisted reduction of GO to achieve holey graphene with abundant in-plane nanopores.[150] The asprepared holey graphene suspension was vacuum filtered to make a binder-free film electrode for EDLC. The porous layered
structure demonstrates high packing density, resulting in relatively high volumetric capacitance and gravimetric capacitance (216 F cm−3, 251 F g−1 at current density of 1 A g−1). The asprepared holey graphene film electrode showed a remarkable enhancement in the current response compared to the film electrode prepared without the hole etching process. This improvement in energy storage capacity is owing to the fast ion adsorption mechanism in the holey graphene electrode. The capacity retention after cycling at high current density (30 A g−1) was 78%, a significant improvement over pristine graphene film electrode (64%). This result implies the positive effect of this unique porous structure to enhance the ion kinetics.
Kim et al. reported scalable graphene nanomeshes (GNMs) with quasiperiodic nanoholes as EDLC electrodes.[151] They used a catalytic carbon gasification process where SnO2 nanoparticles are first deposited on GO, and then carbon is etched by air oxidation during the heating to produce GNMs with a high density of nanoperforations, as shown in Figure 12. The nanoperforation and the enriched edge sites of GNM enable easy ion access and enhance the electrochemical performance (253 F g−1) over pristine graphene (158 F g−1) at a current density of 1 A g−1. Although the conductivity of GNM is a slightly lower than that of pristine graphene, the GNMs showed lower equivalent series resistances (0.97 Ω) than that of pristine graphene (1.33 Ω) because of their ion diffusion properties.
Walsh et al. presented a nonchemical facile single-step air oxidation method to prepare holey graphene; an adequate method for both scalable production and areal capacitance.[152] The as-prepared holey graphene was then physically pressed into mechanically robust monolithic shapes, suitable for direct use as binder-free electrodes. Pristine graphene monoliths prepared through the same process were loosely bound and brittle, therefore inadequate for electrode applications. Xu et al. introduced a cost effective approach to create a hierarchically porous structure of graphene oxide using a cost effective polyurethane sponge as template.[159] Graphene oxide sheets were assembled on the surface of the KOH-fed polyurethane sponge, simultaneously generating both in-plane and out-of-plane pores. sections.heading: 4.2. Application of Porous Graphene for Redox-Based Electrochemical Capacitors
sections.text:
Redox-based electrochemical capacitors are divided into two types: pseudocapacitors and battery-like capacitors, which are easily confused with each other.[160] The charge/discharge profile of pseudocapacitive materials show a linear slope, whereas the battery-like materials exhibit a plateau. Even though pseudocapacitors operate through redox reactions, their galvanostatic behavior is similar to a double layer capacitor, which means they show constant behavior over a wide potential range. On the other hand, battery-like capacitors behave differently depending on the potential range.[161] Thus, the capacitance of pseudocapacitor does not change much depending on the
potential range, while the capacitance of battery-like capacitor is variable.[162] Therefore, redox-based electrochemical capacitors must be carefully distinguished into pseudocapacitor and battery-like capacitor.
The Faradaic pseudocapacitance is generated by fast redox reactions or phase changes that take place on the surface and subsurface of electrodes. Such capacitance offers much higher energy densities than EDLCs.[163] Therefore, much research work deals with the design, preparation, and supercapacitive properties of electrode materials that combine electrostatic and Faradaic reactions to store energy. Active materials such as metal oxides and conducting polymers can remarkably enhance the capacitance, while carbon-based materials can function as support for such materials and

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Pseudocapacitors
sections.text:
A hybrid structure of micro-nanostructured pompon-like MnO2/ graphene hydrogel (GH) composites for high performance supercapacitor applications was reported by Zhang et al.[176]
The pompon-like structure of MnO2/GH limits the aggregation of MnO2 and helps maintain a large active surface area, which can enhance the pseudocapacitive capacitance of the MnO2. Additionally, the porous GH enhances the electrical conductivity and prevents degradation of MnO2. The MnO2/ GH composite electrode exhibits a specific capacitance of 445.7 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, which is a superior result compared to capacitance values of GH (153.5 F g−1) and MnO2 (71.4 F g−1). The specific capacitance remained at 82.4% after 5000 cycles, indicating stable cyclability.
Wei et al. made a 3D graphene structure coated with a MnO2 by simple thermal reduction of GO in water, followed by uniform coating of nanoscale MnO2 controlled by the reaction time of in situ growth.[177] The pores of the 3D graphene aid rapid ionic and electronic transport, while the MnO2 grown on the 3D graphene increases interstitial space between sheets and increases specific surface area from 90 to 209 m2 g−1 and pore volume from 0.47 to 1.30 cm3 g−1. The specific capacitance of MnO2/3D graphene composite reaches 659.7 F g−1 at 0.3 A g−1, a significant increase compared to 2D MnO2/graphene (393 F g−1
at 0.1 A g−1).[178] The retention capability of 106% after 1000 cycles shows the excellent stability of the MnO2/3D graphene composite.
Pan et al. demonstrated a high performance flexible supercapacitor based on a unique composite of carbon nanotube and 3D graphene aerogel, by simply growing CNTs on the surface of 3D graphene aerogel through chemical vapor deposition.[179] The CNT@3D graphene aerogel displays higher electrical conductivity than 3D graphene aerogel alone, and the densely grown CNT greatly increases the effective loading surface for deposition of active materials. An asymmetric supercapacitor was assembled from the positive electrode made out of MnO2 loaded CNT@3D graphene aerogel, and a negative electrode made out of polypyrrole. The optimized asymmetric capacitor featured a stable cycle life and retains up to 84.6% of its initial capacitance after 20 000 cycles. The flexible nature of CNT@3D graphene aerogel enables high capacitance retention of 86.6% even after 500 bending cycles, showing great promise for its application in future flexible electronic devices.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Porous Graphene-Based Electrode Materials for Battery-Like Capacitors
sections.text:
Gao et al. synthesized polyaniline (PANI) nanorod arrays on a GNM.[180] PANI is an attractive material among conductive poly mers due to its high specific capacitance (2000 F g−1), environmental stability, low cost, and the protonated nitrogen atoms that easily bind with metal ions to form PANI/metal oxide composites during hydrothermal treatment.[181–183] The high pseudocapacitance of PANI and GNMs is due to the numerous perforations that shorten the ion pathway and make the entire structure highly penetrable by the electrolyte. The vertically aligned PANI nanorod provides electrochemically active sites. The composite contains 70 wt% PANI and exhibits a specific capacitance of 452 and 404 F g−1 at 1.0 and 50 A g−1, as shown in Figure 13. Other electrochemical properties such as capacitance retention, specific capacitance, and internal resistance of PANI on GNMs are better than PANI on reduced graphene oxides without in-plane nanopores.

The synthesis of 3D porous graphene/polyaniline/Co3O4 ternary hybrid aerogel (GPC) was demonstrated by Lin et al., where PANI/Co3O4 nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the surface of graphene nanosheets.[184] Co3O4, which has a high theoretical capacitance of 3560 F g−1, was combined with PANI and graphene to greatly increase the total capacitance.[183] GO/PANI was in situ polymerized, followed by the selfassembly of GO/cobalt salt hybrid sols to form GPC through hydrothermal treatment. The as-prepared material possesses good performance with high specific capacitance (1247 F g−1). This excellent performance can be attributed to the high pseudocapacitance of PANI and Co3O4, and the 3D porous structure that helps shorten diffusion path length for fast electron transportation.
Another example of porous graphene–polymer composite was reported by He et al. A unique interconnected porous graphene aerogel uniformly embedded with polypyrrole (PPy) nanoparticles was prepared through a simple hydrothermal assembly at low temperature.[166] The embedded PPy nanoparticles prevent the restacking of porous graphene sheets. Moreover, the combination of PPy nanoparticles and porous graphene sheets exhibits specific capacitance as high as 418 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, outstanding rate capability of 80% at current densities ranging from 0.5 to 20 A g−1, and stable cycling performance (74%) after 2000 cycles. Such capacitance behavior is ascribed to the electrical conductivity from porous graphene sheets, abundant interstitial space for ion transport from the 3D hierarchical porous structure with embedded PPy nanoparticles (PPy NPs), and the available active sites. The results show that relatively larger PPy nanoparticles are favorable for good capacitive performance because wider spaces between porous graphene sheets can better prevent the volume change of PPy chains.
Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are also good candidates for supercapacitor electrode materials. They are inorganic multimetal materials that consist of divalent and trivalent cations and charge-balancing anions.[185,186] LDHs can achieve significantly improved supercapacitor performance, thanks to multiple oxidation states available for reversible faradaic reactions and large surface area. However, the interactions between hydrogen bonding in the layered sheets often result in low specific surface area caused by particle aggregation and degrade the supercapacitive performance.[187] Moreover, the poor electrical conductivity of transition metal LDHs is also unfavorable to their electrochemical performance.[188] Graphene can be employed to overcome these shortcomings and enhance the supercapacitive performance of LDH materials with its extremely large surface area, good mechanical flexibility, chemical and thermal stability, and efficient currentcollecting functions.[187,189–192]
Cai et al. proposed a unique and highly uniform composite material composed of porous NiCo–LDH and reduced graphene oxide as supercapacitor electrode.[193] The typical synthesis is as follows: nickel and cobalt precursors are added to the GO suspension, where the positively charged metal ions are electrostatically absorbed onto the surfaces of GO sheets. The adsorbed ions then react with the hydroxyl ions to produce hydroxide monomers, followed by olation reaction of the monomers to form primary particles, which gradually
aggregate and transform into nanosheets on GO.[194] The pores in the nanosheets are generated from the discharged ammonia gas during the synthesis and GO is thermally converted to rGO with methanol as reducing agent.[195] rGO not only enhances charge transfer of NiCo–LDH but also prevents aggregation of the NiCo–LDH nanosheets, acting as an effective matrix to anchor the NiCo–LDH nanosheets for better access of electrolyte ions. The as-prepared NiCo–LDH/ rGO displays excellent supercapacitive properties, delivering a maximum specific capacitance of 1911.1 F g−1 at 2.0 A g−1, which still remains as high as 1469.8 F g−1 at the high current density of 20 A g−1. Capacitance retention of 74% is observed after 1000 cycles at 20 A g−1, making NiCo–LDH/rGO composite a promising candidate for applications in energy storage and conversion.

sections.heading: 5. Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Porous graphene-based nanomaterials are promising candidates for electrochemical energy storage devices. Supercapacitors and batteries that use graphene-based electrodes often suffer from restacking of graphene sheets, which means their practical energy storage performance is below the theoretical maximum. In-plane and out-of-plane porous graphene allow the electrolyte and ions to access a higher degree of the graphene surface area. This allows for improved performance of the capacitors, since their capacitance is proportional to the accessible surface area, and faster battery recharge times. Additionally, the long-term stability can be enhanced by 3D porous structures such as graphene hydrogel and graphene foam, since they prevent the graphene sheets from restacking.
In the past few years, the surge in published research work has allowed rapid advances in the development of materials that incorporate porous graphene. However, precise control of hierarchical pore morphology during the preparation of porous graphene nanocomposites remains a challenge that needs to be addressed in the future. Before porous graphene can be successfully incorporated into real energy storage devices, several issues related to the synthesis process such as the cost, scalability, and long-term stability need to be addressed.
Additionally, special attention should be paid to the volumetric energy and power density when judging the performance of porous materials. Numerous out-of-plane 3D porous materials such as graphene foams and graphene aerogels have been reported to possess improved electrochemical performance per unit mass. However, this could mean a large increase in volume to achieve the claimed performance. For many industrial applications, the marginal increase in performance is not worth the considerable increase in volume. Unfortunately, many research papers neglect to report on the performance per unit volume, and thereby make it difficult to judge the potential applicability or make a fair comparison between different materials.
Nevertheless, we envision that future innovations in the preparation method of porous graphene will lead to the development of many novel nanomaterials that can play an important role in the pursuit of superior energy storage devices.

As for CNTs, despite their high electrical conductivity and large SSA, the intrinsic impurities caused by catalyst reactions and high cost hamper their efficient use. In this sense, graphene is an excellent alternative to conventional carbon electrode materials. Graphene possesses superior physicochemical stability, electrical conductivity, and larger theoretical specific surface area than most conventional carbon materials. Additionally, it also has excellent flexibility and tensile strength, beneficial for possible applications in flexible electrodes.[22–25] These properties make graphene-based nanomaterials the ideal electrode material for electrochemical devices, such as batteries or supercapacitors, which are used in micro-electromechanical systems, electric vehicles, portable electronic devices, etc. For the purpose of this article, a wider definition of “graphene” will be used that includes reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as well. Over the last decade, numerous electrode materials based on graphene have been investigated and tested for cycle stability and their specific capacity.[26–37] However, despite serious research efforts in graphene-based electrochemical energy storage devices, the market demand for higher performance is steadily increasing. In the case of lithium-ion batteries, lithium ions have to make a big detour to reach the electrolyte since they cannot pass through the 2D graphene sheets. This results in a long diffusion distance and consequently a slow charge–discharge rate for lithium-ion batteries.[38,39] Supercapacitors can store electrical charge proportional to the surface area of their conductive material, which makes graphene with a theoretical specific surface of 2600 m2 g−1 per sheet a very promising option.[40] Unfortunately, the widespread use of supercapacitors is limited due to the high effective series resistance and low energy storage density. Additionally, the tendency of graphene sheets to aggregate greatly reduces the real accessible surface area. Additionally, the combination of versatile functionalization chemistry and simplicity of large-scale synthesis makes graphene ideal for electrode materials for energy storage devices. To improve the electrochemical performance even further, recent research has focused on the preparation of porous graphene structures, either by creating holes in the graphene sheets or by assembling them into a 3D porous framework. Porous graphene and reduced graphene oxide allow for rapid ion diffusion and display high real surface area. In this review paper, the conventional methods for the preparation of porous graphene are summarized and recent progress in porous graphene-based nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage devices is discussed.
